description:
Peromyscus leucopus, commonly known as the white-footed mouse, is a small rodent species native to North America. It belongs to the genus Peromyscus, which includes several species of deer mice.

The white-footed mouse is characterized by its small size, typically weighing between 15-30 grams. It has a slender body, large eyes, and large ears relative to its head size. The fur coloration is brownish-gray on the upper parts and white on the underside, with white feet and a white-tipped tail.

This species is widely distributed across the eastern and central regions of North America, ranging from Canada to Mexico. It is found in a variety of habitats, including deciduous forests, grasslands, and urban areas.

White-footed mice are primarily nocturnal and arboreal, spending much of their time foraging for food, which includes seeds, nuts, berries, and insects. They are known for their excellent climbing and jumping abilities, allowing them to navigate their environment efficiently.

Peromyscus leucopus plays an important role in the ecosystem as a prey species for various predators, such as snakes, owls, and small carnivores. They also contribute to the dispersal of seeds and the regulation of insect populations.

Due to their adaptability and widespread distribution, white-footed mice are considered a common and abundant species throughout their range. However, their populations can be affected by habitat loss, fragmentation, and the use of rodenticides.
